stem: Which nursing actions are most appropriate for the patient at this time?

patient.chiefComplaint: Fever, shortness of breath, and confusion

itemContext.sbar: Patient is a 78-year-old male admitted from home with fever, shortness of breath, and altered mental status. He has a history of COPD, hypertension, and Type 2 Diabetes. Vital signs are: Temp 102.5Â°F, HR 110 bpm, RR 28 breaths/min, BP 90/60 mmHg, SpO2 90% on 2L nasal cannula. Labs pending. Patient is confused and disoriented to place and time. Physician notified.

rationale.correct: The patient exhibits signs and symptoms of sepsis (fever, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypotension, altered mental status, elevated WBC, elevated lactate, elevated procalcitonin). Prompt intervention is crucial to improve outcomes. Administering IV fluids addresses the hypotension and tissue hypoperfusion. Administering prescribed antibiotics is essential for treating the infection causing the sepsis. Monitoring urine output is essential for assessing fluid status and renal perfusion. Elevating the head of the bed promotes lung expansion and improves oxygenation.
rationale.incorrect: Withholding antibiotics increases the risk of mortality in septic patients. Waiting for chest X-ray results before initiating antibiotics delays treatment. Lowering the head of the bed may worsen respiratory compromise. Delaying IV fluid administration can worsen hypotension and hypoperfusion. Deferring blood cultures delays identification of the causative organism.
clinicalPearls: Early recognition and treatment of sepsis are critical to improve patient outcomes.
The Surviving Sepsis Campaign provides guidelines for managing sepsis.
Fluid resuscitation and antibiotics are cornerstones of sepsis management.
Monitor for signs of fluid overload during fluid resuscitation.
Obtain blood cultures prior to initiating antibiotic therapy.

questionTrap.commonMistake: Prioritizing interventions based on habit or familiarity rather than clinical urgency.
questionTrap.whyMistakeHappens: Lack of a systematic approach to prioritizing care, failure to recognize the severity of sepsis, and inadequate knowledge of sepsis management guidelines.

mnemonic.name: SEPSIS
mnemonic.description: Signs & Symptoms, Evaluate Source, Prevent Hypotension, Stabilize Oxygenation, Implement Antibiotics, Support Organ Function
mnemonic.application: Use this mnemonic to guide your assessment and interventions for patients with suspected sepsis.

options.text: Withhold antibiotics until chest X-ray results are available.
Lower the head of the bed to promote circulation.
Elevate the head of the bed.
Defer blood cultures until the patient is more stable.
